results.title: Stack
results.brief_description: In ‘Stack’, sound artist Ros Bandt captures sounds from the city stack emissions, a 55 metre chimney stack that extracts fumes from the Citylink tunnel. Sounds from the cylinder, the external grid and internal resonant surfaces, along with ambient sounds of the industrial extractor fans and builders working were recorded. Sections of the steel frame were electrified in order to generate original percussion timbres. The tunnel footage was shot and edited by Martin Wright.

results.title: 70 years at Brunswick Baths
results.brief_description: Brunswick - Harry Ivory, a fitness fanatic, a boxer, boxing trainer and local legend has been attending the Brunswick Baths since the day it opened in 1928. Part of a longer documentary about Harry’s life, this 4 minute film was made especially for the MAP project and focuses on the importance to him of the Brunswick Baths and the Baths community. Harry loves the place and often says it is the Baths that keep him going.

results.title: Froggie's gone
results.brief_description: This warmly comic documentary is about Beryl from Brunswick whose prized garden frog is stolen from her verandah. Very soon the police and the neighbours are on the trail of the thieves, everyone wanting to do their bit to ensure that Froggie comes back home where he belongs. This acclaimed short film was made by Beryl’s niece as a celebration of community, and is an example of how remembering an episode from your life can make a wonderful piece of film.

results.title: The Street
results.creator_credit: Caroline Leaf, Guy Glover, National Film Board of Canada and Wolf Koenig
results.brief_description: This award-winning animation film spares no feelings and minces no words. A poignant interpretation of a short story by Montreal author Mordecai Richler, it makes what is sometimes an embarrassingly frank statement about how many families respond to their old and infirm members. In soft simple washes of watercolour and ink, the filmmaker interprets reactions to a dying grandmother, capturing family feelings and distilling them into harsh reality.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Caroline Leaf, Guy Glover, National Film Board of Canada and Wolf Koenig

results.title: Two sisters
results.creator_credit: Caroline Leaf and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Viola lives her life in isolation, hiding her disfigured face from the outside world in a darkened room where she writes her novels. Marie, her sister and only companion, takes care of her every need, acting as her protector from the cruelty she perceives surrounds them. The two women happily live as co-dependant social pariahs until a male stranger arrives and throws their tenuous order into chaos. Caroline Leaf’s masterful animated short explores the psychological ramifications of isolation and the distortions it can create in a persons mind.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Caroline Leaf and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Mallboy and sound design
results.brief_description: Speakers: Philip Brophy (Sound Designer) Vincent Girusso (Director/Writer) Fiona Eagger (Producer) discussing the decisions they made for the sound design of ‘Mallboy’. This was a presentation for Cinesonic conference 2000 filmed for research purposes only.

results.title: Cyberdelia
results.credit_line:
Steve Spangaro, director
Mike Collins, associate director
Milena Romanin, production manager
Susan King, interviews and research
Based on an original concept by Adem Jaffers
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
Cyberdelia is a visceral encounter with the aesthetic and ideals of Melbourne underground cyber artists at the confluence of analogue and digital creative practice in 1991.

In blending artist interviews and works, this magazine style documentary explores visions of personal and cultural enhancement through transformative digital technologies. The imminent fusion of spirituality with technology; flesh with machine and psychedelia with cybernetics is confidently proclaimed.

Cyberdelia is a visual and aural feast with the film-makers channelling the post-modern mischief and transcendental yearnings of the ‘cyberdelic’ movement to radical stylistic effect. Stunning cyber artist works are liberally leveraged as both feature material and interstitial fodder. Low-budget analogue video editing and compositing tools are pushed to the limit while artist on-camera interviews are staged in bizarre fashion so as to maintain the feel of a ‘trip documentary’ from start to finish.

Cyberdelia stretches the boundaries of arts documentary to portray the brazen idealism and micro-processor powered creativity of these pre World Wide Web visionaries. Produced for community television and first broadcast on RMITV, Cyberdelia was later shown on SKA-TV and other Australian community television test transmissions. It was also selected for the Sixth Australian International Video Festival (1991).

Artists: Acid Death Bed, Misha Hollenbach, Troy Innocent (Cyber Dada), Natalie Jeremijenko, Adem Jaffers (Neuro), Jeff Jaffers (Third Eye), Dale Nason (Cyber Dada), Ollie Olsen (Third Eye) Captain ROM, Stelarc, Gus Till (Third Eye), Julian Wong, Christopher Wright and Max Q.

Cyberdelia was generously donated to ACMI by Cyberdelia Productions.

results.title: Burnout 2001
results.brief_description: Burnout 2001 is an interactive game which allows users to use a catalogue of authentic burnout movements to create various markings on the screen. A variety of vehicle’s available each having a particular speciality to their burnout.
results.description: Burnout 2001 is an interactive game which allows users to use a catalogue of authentic burnout movements to create various markings on the screen. A variety of vehicle’s available each having a particular speciality to their burnout.

results.title: This is my world
results.brief_description: Leanne is a virtual popstar. The artist dressed as the character Leanne (modeled on an anime character) sings a sorrowful pop song about her lonely world. The video is shot in the liminal no-place space of the Shopping Centre.
